review_title: I wish I found Liberty Hospital sooner!
job_title: Registered Nurse Manager in Liberty, MO
pros: Liberty Hospital is a place where small-town feel meets modern, first-rate healthcare. Being a clinician, it is refreshing to come to work each day knowing that I work at an organization that is not for profit and purely motivated by high quality standards and positive patient outcomes. All employees have a voice, unlike other huge organizations where our voices are lost in the crowd.
cons: Available positions are hard fleeting. People love it here and tend to stay for their entire career. If a position opens, it's not for long.

review_title: This is my Employer of Choice for 17.5 years and continues to be!!

review_title: No Opportunity and Inequal Pay for Same Job
job_title: Environmental Services Aide II in Liberty, MO
pros: They offer night shift which works for certain individuals' schedules.
cons: I have worked here 5 years night shift.  My department cut over and over because ER and other departments wanted "their own" dedicated cleaning staff.  So my department shrank because these departments received their own staff.... But they only received their own staff for days.  So my department shrank....I am literally the ONLY person on nightshift, yet I'm supposed still cover ALL departments for the night by myself.  The worst part?  I've been carrying the phone which is a supervisor duty since I've been working here.  About a year ago, they started paying everyone else a dollar more an hour whenever they carry the phone.... But I still do not get that dollar extra for carry the phone!!!!  Same Job, others receive a dollar more for it!!!!  And final straw?  I have been to about 6 interviews for supervisor and sterile processing and every time the interviewer barely speaks to me.  They are busy on the phone or dealing with their department.  My boss even said he wouldn't let me move up anyway because I'm the only employee he has left.  There is no opportunity and no consideration to hire and retain dedicated employees.  Steer clear of this dead end facility.

pros: Great Benefits, the program had come a long way
cons: very physical, the pay is low

pros: Good pay/benefits but that's it! People in some departments are nice but extremely rude in others. Don't waste your time here. My fellow nurses in my unit are great but I have seen other departments that are very less willing to lend a hand when asked.
cons: They are very strict on unscheduled absences and don't care what your reasoning is. HIM department is horribly unorganized with no direction. Hospital tries to dictate everything the employees do and do not allow you to leave the premises during lunch. Hospital only cares about money and not about their patients. They solicit patients in there rooms in an attempt to get them to sign up for their online records portal and they have a quota they must meet.

job_title: Float Certified Nursing Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Flexible schedule, many hours available, perfect job for a student due to flexibility
cons: Some nurses in management roles lack proper management skills. Favoritism and uncaring staff exist as is in all healthcare systems currently. Overloaded like many healthcare operations as of right now. Nurses attitudes, when negative or uncaring need to be addressed, not ignored or embraced with an advancement.

pros: Small town feel - people stay there their entire careers. Deal with mostly business in Northland.
cons: People stay there their whole careers and the organization does not get new ideas until they hire outside. Facility is dated. Job descriptions written around individuals and not the jobs.  They pay outsiders more than their employees with longevity. High turnover.

pros: Liberty Hospital has caring and compassionate employees. When working through any situations, the goal of the patient experience seems to always be top of mind. Liberty Hospital has had some changes to leadership and they've been great additions. Cohesion and communication seems improved.
cons: Need to continue to work on processes for when changes are needed, and upgraded systems.

review_title: Great place to work and grow
job_title: Clinic Coordinator in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great Hospital to work for. I have been with this company for a while. There are always opportunities for growth and ways to better your skills. I admire the team I work with and enjoy the patients so much.
cons: Paid time off comes out of one bank. Holidays, sick days and vacation days are all in one. You don't get much time for all.

pros:
Our Hope Is that is that we meet our mission here.

Our Mission - The Mission of Liberty Hospital is to work in partnership with our community to improve the health and well being of those we serve.

Our Vision - To be the leader in providing high quality, patient centered care.

Our Values - We take PRIDE in the work that we do, and it is based upon the values of:

Partnership –with each other and our customers

Responsibility – the effective use of our resources in order to maintain financial viability

Integrity – in business and human relationships

Dignity – treating every person with compassion and respect

Excellence – in clinical and customer service results
cons:
Quality and Performance evaluations have become critical issues at Liberty Hospital and Clinics. . Care is sub-optimal in many different medical conditions and clinical settings throughout the organization. Although delivering high-quality care is important to all clinicians, this issue may be particularly relevant to certain subgroups, such as nurses, physicians, leadership and P.I. department. You also see less specialized training and those who seek no interaction from patients and those who spend time or see a smaller volume of patients compared to others. The tragic thing when you look at Performance improvement department and Core Measures and the lack of quality initiatives identified fall directly with leadership. While they should be coordinating, educating  and implementing improvements to identify gaps in performance it comes truly comes down to not caring for the patients and follow through as you can review in H.C.A.H.P.S. (Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems).
Physicians have a caudle affect especially those who have been in practice for more years, or those that fundamentally do not actually care may also be less likely to deliver high-quality care. Medical advances occur frequently, and the explicit knowledge that physicians possess may easily become out of date. Therefore, although it is generally assumed that the tacit knowledge and skills accumulated by physicians during years of practice lead to superior clinical abilities; it is also plausible that physicians with more experience may paradoxically be less likely to provide technically appropriate care.
Performance Improvement department becomes a performance circle scenario and data remains inaccurate throughout the organization. When you review how important existing studies have had with specific goals of evaluating the effects of experience on the quality of medical care. However, length of time in clinical practice has been included as part of a set of physician characteristics this too might explain variations in quality or that may be con-founders of the association between quality and other factors.
Ultimately it comes down to fictitious data that’s easily manipulated to lean one way or the other by the interpreter. This does not support  accuracy and builds animosity and deconstructs the purpose of Liberty Hospital. 

Turnover continues and we lose quality team members not over benefits or wages but actions.

CARE
